title: Tipping Tips For the Digital Age: How to Master the Gratuity Grind
text:
Buy vs Lease: Your New Car Decision Time 
NEW YORK (MainStreet) -- Tipping in the digital, peer-to-peer economy is a tricky endeavor . It's the gratuity version of that old exercise of " threading the needle ," where consumers want to balance appreciation of service with accountability of service for the Ubers and AirBnBs of the emerging digital world. Even old-school consumer experiences, like paying for a meal at a restaurant, are thrown off kilter when diners order their own food without a waiter (via tableside tablets like the ones offered by Applebee's, which require no human interaction to order that double cheeseburger with fries, cooked minimum rare, along with an unsweetened ice tea.) Another wrinkle is the odd, rather awkward experience of having to choose from three different tipping options on an iPad payment screen while standing face-to-face with your local barista. When selecting 15%, 20% or 25%, should you risk the scorn of your daily latte provider by tapping 15%, or worse, no tip at all? If so, sorry - don't expect a smiley face carved into your foam at the top of that latte - or worse . Oh, the horror. To set things right, let's address some more prominent "modern age" digital tipping situations, and see who gets what, and under what circumstances: 1
